sen.j: 坪内 逍遥（つぼうち しょうよう、正字体：逍遙、1859年6月22日（安政6年5月22日 (旧暦)） - 2月28日）は明治に活躍した日本の小説家、評論家、翻訳家、劇作家。
sen.e: Shoyo TSUBOUCHI (坪内 逍遥, orthographic style: 逍遙, June 22, 1859-February 28, 1935) was a novelist, critic, translator, and playwright in Japan who was active in the Meiji Era.
sen.cmt: 死没の年号が抜けておりましたので、補足致しました。
sen.e: Shoyo TSUBOUCHI (坪内 逍遥, orthographic style: 逍遙, June 22, 1859 - February 28, 1935) was a novelist, critic, translator, and playwright in Japan who was active in the Meiji Era.
Shoyo TSUBOUCHI (坪内 逍遥, orthographic style: 逍遙, June 22, 1859 - February 28, 1935) was a novelist, critic, translator, and playwright in Japan who was active in the Meiji Era.

sen.j: 代表作に『小説神髄』『当世書生気質』およびシェイクスピア全集の翻訳。
sen.e: His best-known works are "Shosetsu Shinzui" (The Essence of Novels), "Tosei shosei katagi" (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) and translated the complete works of Shakespeare.
His best-known works are "Shosetsu Shinzui" (The Essence of Novels), "Tosei shosei katagi" (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) and his translation of the complete works of Shakespeare.
His best-known works are "Shosetsu Shinzui" (The Essence of Novels), "Tosei shosei katagi" (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) and his translation of the complete works of Shakespeare.

sen.j: 本名は坪内雄蔵。
sen.e: His real name is Yuzo TSUBOUCHI.
His real name is Yuzo TSUBOUCHI.
His real name is Yuzo TSUBOUCHI.

sen.j: 別号に春のやおぼろ、春のや主人など。
sen.e: He also called himself Harunoya Oboro or Harunoya Shujin.
He also called himself Oboro HARUNOYA or Shujin HARUNOYA.
He also called himself Oboro HARUNOYA or Shujin HARUNOYA.

sen.j: 戒名は雙柿院始終逍遥居士。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Soushiin Shiju Shoyo Kyoshi (an avid Buddhist who is living in a place that has two persimmon trees, and who likes strolling all the time).
sen.cmt: 雙柿院始終逍遥居士の読みが不明です。また、定訳がありませんでしたが、下記出典先などより推測しました。http://www.ataminews.gr.jp/kankou/18.html
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Soshiin Shiju Shoyo Kyoshi (an avid Buddhist who is living in a place that has two persimmon trees, and who likes strolling all the time).
His posthumous Buddhist name is Soshiin Shiju Shoyo Kyoshi (an avid Buddhist who is living in a place that has two persimmon trees, and who likes strolling all the time).

sen.j: 俳句も詠んだ。
sen.e: He also composed Haiku (a Japanese poem in seventeen syllables having a 5-7-5 syllabic form and traditionally containing a reference to the seasons).
He also composed haiku (a Japanese poem in seventeen syllables having a 5-7-5 syllabic form and traditionally containing a reference to the seasons).
He also composed haiku (a Japanese poem in seventeen syllables having a 5-7-5 syllabic form and traditionally containing a reference to the seasons).

sen.j: 尾張藩の領地だった、美濃国加茂郡 (岐阜県)太田宿 (中山道)（現・岐阜県美濃加茂市）の生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Ota-juku (Nakasen-do Road) (present-day Minokamo City, Gifu Prefecture), Kamo District, Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) where governed by Owari Domain.
He was born in Ota-juku (Nakasen-do Road) (present-day Minokamo City, Gifu Prefecture), Kamo-gun District, Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) which was governed by Owari Domain.
He was born in Ota-juku (Nakasen-do Road) (present-day Minokamo City, Gifu Prefecture), Kamo-gun District, Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) which was governed by Owari Domain.

sen.j: 父は尾張藩士。
sen.e: His father was one of the Owari clansmen.
His father was one of the Owari clansmen.
His father was one of the Owari clansmen.

sen.j: 太田代官所の手代をつとめていたが、のちに一家で実家のある名古屋へ戻った。
sen.e: He was working as a clerk at Ota daikansho (regional office of administrative official), but later, he and all of his family members moved to Nagoya where his family home was located.
He was working as a clerk at Ota daikansho (regional office of administrative official), but later, he and all of his family members moved to Nagoya where his family home was located.
He was working as a clerk at Ota daikansho (regional office of administrative official), but later, he and all of his family members moved to Nagoya where his family home was located.

sen.j: 母の影響を受け、幼くして読本・草双紙などの江戸文学や俳諧、和歌に親しむ。
sen.e: He was influenced by his mother, and immersed himself in literatures of the Edo period such as Yomihon (copy for reading), Kusazoshi (book with a wealth of illustrations), and Haikai (seventeen-syllable verse), Waka (classical Japanese verse) at his early age.

He was influenced by his mother, and immersed himself in literature of the Edo period such as Yomihon (books for reading), Kusazoshi (books with a wealth of illustrations), as well as Haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) and Waka (classical Japanese verse) at an early age.

He was influenced by his mother, and immersed himself in literature of the Edo period such as Yomihon (books for reading), Kusazoshi (books with a wealth of illustrations), as well as Haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) and Waka (classical Japanese verse) at an early age.

sen.j: 洋学校（現・愛知県立旭丘高等学校）、東京大学予備門（のちの第一高等学校 (旧制)）を経て、東京大学（のちの東京帝国大学）文学部政治科卒業、文学士（当時は文学士といっても理学に対する文学なので文学を専攻したわけではない）。
sen.e: He studied at Yogakko (School of Western Studies) (present-day Aichi Prefectural Asahigaoka High School), Tokyo Yobimon (Preparatory School of the University of Tokyo)(later became Daiichi High School [the first old-education-system high school]), graduated from the Department of Politics, the Faculty of Letters of The University of Tokyo (later became the Tokyo Imperial University), Bachelor of Arts (however, it was literary studies on the science, consequently it doesn't mean that he's majored in literature at that time).

He studied at Yogakko (School of Western Studies) (present-day Aichi Prefectural Asahigaoka High School), Tokyo Yobimon (Preparatory School of the University of Tokyo) (later became Daiichi High School [the first old-education-system high school]), graduated with a Bachelor of Arts from the Department of Politics, Faculty of Letters of the University of Tokyo (later became Tokyo Imperial University). (However, it was literary studies in regards to science, meaning he did not necessarily major in literature).

He studied at Yogakko (School of Western Studies) (present-day Aichi Prefectural Asahigaoka High School), Tokyo Yobimon (Preparatory School of the University of Tokyo) (later became Daiichi High School [the first old-education-system high school]), graduated with a Bachelor of Arts (this Arts is just a contrast to Science, meaning he did not necessarily major in Arts) from the Department of Politics, Faculty of Letters of the University of Tokyo (later became Tokyo Imperial University).
sen.cmt: 末尾の（）は内容を改変し位置を移動しました

sen.j: 東京専門学校（のちの早稲田大学）講師となり、のちに早大教授。
sen.e: He became an instructor at Tokyo Senmon Gakko (later became the Waseda University), and became a professor of Waseda University afterward.
He became an instructor at Tokyo Senmon Gakko (later became Waseda University), and later became a professor at Waseda University.
He became an instructor at Tokyo Senmon Gakko (later became Waseda University), and later became a professor at Waseda University.

sen.j: 26歳で評論『小説神髄』を発表。
sen.e: When he was 26 years old, he published his criticism "The Essence of Novels".
When he was 26 years old, he published his criticism "The Essence of Novels".
When he was 26 years old, he published his criticism "The Essence of Novels".

sen.j: 江戸時代の勧善懲悪の物語を否定し、小説はまず人情を描くべきで世態風俗の描写がこれに次ぐと論じた。
sen.e: He denied tales that rewards good and punishes evil which was preferred in Edo period, and he has stated that a novel should depict the human empathy first, and the depiction of times and folkways follows next.

He denied tales that rewards good and punishes evil which was preferred in Edo period, and he has stated that a novel should depict the human empathy first, followed by the depiction of times and folkways.

He denied tales that rewards good and punishes evil which was preferred in Edo period, and he has stated that a novel should depict the human empathy first, followed by the depiction of times and folkways.

sen.j: この心理的写実主義によって日本の近現代文学史の誕生に大きく貢献した。
sen.e: He made a huge contribution to the establishment of literary history in the modern times and the present day by this psychological realism.
He made a huge contribution to the establishment of literary history in both modern times and the present day by this psychological realism.
He made a huge contribution to the establishment of literary history in both modern times and the present day by this psychological realism.

sen.j: また、その理論を実践すべく小説『当世書生気質』を著した。
sen.e: Further, he wrote Tosei shosei katagi (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) to implement the theory.
Further, he wrote Tosei shosei katagi (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) to implement the theory.
Further, he wrote Tosei shosei katagi (The Character of Modern Students, 1885-6) to implement the theory.

sen.j: しかし逍遙自身がそれまでの戯作文学の影響から脱しきれておらず、これらの近代文学観が不完全なものに終っていることが、後に二葉亭四迷の『小説総論』『浮雲 (二葉亭四迷)』によって批判的に示された（『浮雲』第一編は営業上の理由で坪内雄蔵名義で刊行された）。
sen.e: However, he was still not quite free of influence on Gesaku (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature) literature himself, and later, the incompleteness of these modern literature standpoints were critically indicated by FUTABATEI Shimei in "Shosetsu Soron"(general remarks of a novel), "Ukigumo (FUTABATEI Shimei)" (Floating Clouds) (the first "Ukigumo" was published in the name of Yuzo TSUBOUCHI, because of its commercial reason).
sen.cmt: 『浮雲 (二葉亭四迷)』の括弧内は、前文にかかる重複と思われますので、省いても良い火と思われます。
sen.e: However, he was still not quite free of influence from Gesaku (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature) literature himself, and later, the incompleteness of these modern literature standpoints were critically indicated by FUTABATEI Shimei in "Shosetsu Soron"(general remarks of a novel), "Ukigumo (FUTABATEI Shimei)" (Floating Clouds) (the first "Ukigumo" was published in the name of Yuzo TSUBOUCHI for commercial reasons).
sen.cmt: Wording. (Is FUTABATEI Shimei correct? Should it not be Shimei FUTABATEI as per instructions?
sen.e: However, he was still not quite free of influence from Gesaku (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature) literature himself, and later, the incompleteness of these modern literature standpoints were critically indicated by Shimei FUTABATEI in "Shosetsu Soron"(general remarks of a novel), "Ukigumo (Shimei FUTABATEI)" (Floating Clouds) (the first "Ukigumo" was published in the name of Yuzo TSUBOUCHI for commercial reasons).

sen.j: 小説のほか戯曲も書き、演劇の近代化に果たした役割も大きい。
sen.e: He wrote a play as well as a novel, and he had played a great role to modernization on plays.
He wrote plays as well as novels, and he played a great role in modernization of plays.
He wrote plays as well as novels, and he played a great role in modernization of plays.

sen.j: 新歌舞伎『桐一葉』『沓手鳥孤城落月』『お夏狂乱』『牧の方』を書いた。
sen.e: He wrote shin kabuki (new kabuki) "Kiri Hitoha" (A Paulownia Leaf), "Hototogisu Kojo no Rakugetsu" (The Sinking Moon over the Lonely Castle Where the Cuckoo Cries), "Onatsu Kyoran" (Onatsu's Madness), "Maki no kata" (Lady Maki).

He wrote shin kabuki (new kabuki) "Kiri Hitoha" (A Paulownia Leaf), "Hototogisu Kojo no Rakugetsu" (The Sinking Moon over the Lonely Castle Where the Cuckoo Cries), "Onatsu Kyoran" (Onatsu's Madness), and "Maki no kata" (Lady Maki).

He wrote shin kabuki (new kabuki) "Kiri Hitoha" (A Paulownia Leaf), "Hototogisu Kojo no Rakugetsu" (The Sinking Moon over the Lonely Castle Where the Cuckoo Cries), "Onatsu Kyoran" (Onatsu's Madness), and "Maki no kata" (Lady Maki).

sen.j: また、、島村抱月らと文芸協会を開設し、新劇運動の先駆けとなった。
sen.e: In 1906, He established an Association of Literature with Hougetsu SHIMAMURA, and it set a precedent for the movement of shingeki (literally, new play).
sen.cmt: 年号が抜けておりましたので、補足致しました。
sen.e: In 1906, he established the Association of Literature with Hougetsu SHIMAMURA, and it set a precedent for the movement of shingeki (literally, new play).
sen.cmt: Wording. (Shouldn't it be "Hogetsu SHIMAMURA" as per instruction?)
sen.e: In 1906, he established the Association of Literature with Hogetsu SHIMAMURA and others, and it set a precedent for the movement of shingeki (literally, new play).
sen.cmt: ・Hougetsu SHIMAMURA→Hogetsu SHIMAMURA・「ら」を訳出しました

sen.j: 雑誌『早稲田文学』の成立にも貢献した。
sen.e: Additionally, he contributed to launching the premiere issue of a magazine, "Waseda Bungaku" (Waseda Literature).
Additionally, he contributed to launching the premiere issue of the magazine, "Waseda Bungaku" (Waseda Literature).

sen.j: 早稲田大学の演劇博物館は、逍遙のウィリアム・シェイクスピア全訳の偉業を記念して建設されたものである。
sen.e: The Tsubouchi Memorial Theatre Museum of Waseda University was constructed to commemorate Shoyo's accomplishments that translated the complete works of William SHAKESPEARE.

sen.j: 「沙翁全集」全40冊、第一編（12月）のみ富山房と早稲田大学出版部との共同出版、第二編以降は早稲田大学出版部の単独出版。
sen.e: "Sao zenshu" (the complete works of William SHAKESPEARE) was composed of 40 books, and only the first book (December, 1909) was published jointly by Fuzanbo and Waseda University Press, and the Waseda University Press published independently remaining books after the second book.
sen.cmt: 年号が抜けておりましたので、補足致しました。
sen.e: "Sao zenshu" (the complete works of William SHAKESPEARE) was composed of 40 books, and only the first book (December 1909) was published jointly by Fuzanbo and Waseda University Press, and the Waseda University Press independently published the remaining books after the second book.

"Sao zenshu" (the complete works of William SHAKESPEARE) was composed of 40 books, of which only the first book (December 1909) was published jointly by Fuzanbo and Waseda University Press, and the remaining books including the second were independently published by the Waseda University Press.

sen.j: 第40編は著述で「シェークスピア研究栞」（12月刊行）。
sen.e: The 40th book was a literary work "Shakespeare Kenkyu Shiori" (research guidebook of Shakespeare) (published in December, 1928), and at first, it was called as "Sao Kessakushu" (the masterpieces of Shakespeare) until the 23rd book, and changed the title to "Sao zenshu" (the complete works of Shakespeare) after the 24th book, and changed entire book's titles including first books as "Sao Zenshu" afterward.
sen.cmt: 年号が抜けておりましたので、補足致しました。
sen.e: The 40th book was a literary work titled "Shakespeare Kenkyu Shiori" (research guidebook of Shakespeare) (published in December 1928). It was first titled "Sao Kessakushu" (the masterpieces of Shakespeare) until the 23rd book, followed by "Sao zenshu" (the complete works of Shakespeare) after the 24th book. The entire book's titles including the first books were changed to "Sao Zenshu" thereafter.
The 40th book was a literary work titled "Shakespeare Kenkyu Shiori" (research guidebook of Shakespeare) (published in December 1928).
sen.cmt: 3文に訳されていたので、一原文一訳文となるよう処理しました一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 当初第23編迄は「沙翁傑作集」と称し、第24編より「沙翁全集」と改称、以後最初の分も「沙翁全集」と改称。
sen.e: It was first titled "Sao Kessakushu" (the masterpieces of Shakespeare) until the 23rd book, followed by "Sao zenshu" (the complete works of Shakespeare) after the 24th book, then the entire book's titles including the first books were changed to "Sao Zenshu" thereafter.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 「新修シェークスピア全集」全20函（全40冊、1函に２冊収納）中央公論社。
sen.e: "Shinshu Shakespeare Zenshu" (newly compiled the complete works of Shakespeare) total 20 boxes (total 40 books, two books enclosed in the one box) Chuo Koronsha.
"Shinshu Shakespeare Zenshu" (newly compiled complete works of Shakespeare), a total of 20 boxes (total of 40 books, with two books enclosed in the one box) published by Chuo Koronsha.
"Shinshu Shakespeare Zenshu" (newly compiled complete works of Shakespeare), a total of 20 boxes (total of 40 books, with two books enclosed in the one box) were published by Chuo Koronsha.

sen.j: 上記早大出版部本の改訂だが「オセロー」など殆ど新稿と云っても良いほど面目を新たにしている。
sen.e: The revised book of aforementioned book published by Waseda University Press such as "Othello" had changed completely, it can be said that is nearly new book.
The revised editions of the aforementioned books published by Waseda University Press such as "Othello" have changed completely, and it can be said that they are like new books.
It was the revised editions of the aforementioned books published by Waseda University Press, and they were like new books including "Othello" which had changed completely,

sen.j: （9月より5月迄配本）以後この版を底本として戦後に創元社（全１冊）、新樹社（分冊）等から新版が出されている。
sen.e: (Distributed from September, 1933 to May, 1935) Afterward, using this version as an original, new editions were published by Sogensha (total one book), and Shinjusha (separate volume) in the postwar period.
sen.cmt: 最初の（）は、前文に添えたほうが良いように思われます。また、年号が抜けておりましたので、補足致しました。創元社の定訳として、Tokyo Sogensha Co., Ltd.とありますが、元は創元社のようですので、その様に訳出しました。出典：http://www.sogensha.co.jp/com_en/index.html
sen.e: (Distributed from September 1933 to May 1935) Afterwards, using this version as an original, new editions were published by Sogensha (total of one book), and Shinjusha (separate volume) in the postwar period.
sen.cmt: Wording. As the translator has commented, the first sentence in parenthesis should be part of the previous sentence, thus would read "(distributed from September 1933 to May 1935).". Also, is "using this version as an original" referring to Othello or all of the revised editions of all the aformentioned books? If it is all editions, I think it should read "using these versions as originals".
sen.e: (Distributed from September 1933 to May 1935) Afterwards, using this version as an original, new editions were published by Sogensha (total of one book), and Shinjusha (separate volume) in the postwar period.

sen.j: 中央公論社版は誤植が少なくなく付録月報の「沙翁復興」に正誤表が掲載されている号があるのでそれで訂正して利用すべきである。
sen.e: Since Chuo Koronsha version has quite a lot of erratum, you should use the list of errata that appeared on monthly supplement newsletter "Sao Fukko" (renaissance of Shakespeare) to correct them.

Since the Chuo Koronsha versions have quite a lot of errata, you should use the list of errata that appeared on the monthly supplement newsletter "Sao Fukko" (renaissance of Shakespeare) to correct them.

Since the Chuo Koronsha versions have quite a lot of errata, you should use the list of errata that appeared on the monthly supplement newsletter "Sao Fukko" (renaissance of Shakespeare) to correct them.

sen.j: 妻センは東大の近くにあった根津遊廓の大八幡楼の娼妓・花紫。
sen.e: His wife, Sen was a prostitute called Hanamurasaki at the Dai Hachiman Ro in Nezu yukaku (a brothel in Nezu), he went there frequently to meet her when he was a college student, and they got married in 1886.
sen.cmt: 大八幡楼および花紫の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: His wife, Sen, was a prostitute named Hanamurasaki at the Dai Hachiman Ro in Nezu Yukaku (a brothel in Nezu). He went there frequently to meet her when he was a college student, and they got married in 1886.
His wife, Sen, was a prostitute named Hanamurasaki at the Dai Hachiman Ro, one of Nezu Yukaku (a brothel in Nezu) near the University of Tokyo.
sen.cmt: ・2文として訳されていたので、分割処理を行いました・Hachiman Ro in Nezu Yukaku→Hachiman Ro, one of Nezu Yukaku・「東大の近くにあった」を訳出しました一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 学生であった逍遙が数年間通いつめ、明治19年（1886年）に結婚した。
sen.e: He went there frequently to meet her for several years when he was a college student, and they got married in 1886.
sen.cmt: 「数年間」を訳出しました一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: これをテーマにした松本清張『文豪』がある。
sen.e: There's a Seicho MATSUMOTO's book "Bungo" (great writer) that dealing with this story.
There's a Seicho MATSUMOTO's book "Bungo" (great writer) that dealing with this story.
There's a Seicho MATSUMOTO's book "Bungo" (great writer) that dealing with this story.

sen.j: 二人には子がなく、逍遙は兄義衛の三男・坪内士行（元宝塚歌劇団職員で演劇評論家）を養子としたが後に養子縁組を解消した。
sen.e: They don't have a child, therefore, Shoyo adopted his older brother 義衛's third son Shiko TSUBOUCHI (former personnel of Takarazuka Revue and theater critic), but dissolved the adoption afterward.
sen.cmt: 義衛の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: As they didn't have a child, Shoyo adopted his older brother Giei's third son Shiko TSUBOUCHI (former personnel of Takarazuka Revue and theater critic), but dissolved the adoption afterward.
As they didn't have a child, Shoyo adopted his older brother Giei's third son Shiko TSUBOUCHI (former personnel of Takarazuka Revue and theater critic), but dissolved the adoption afterward.

sen.j: （士行の妻は宝塚歌劇団1期生の雲井浪子、その子は女優・坪内ミキ子）
sen.e: (Shiko's wife is Namiko KUMOI who was first graduates from Takarazuka Revue, and her daughter is an actress Mikiko TSUBOUCHI.)
(Shiko's wife was Namiko KUMOI who was a first graduate of Takarazuka Revue, and her daughter is actress Mikiko TSUBOUCHI.)
(Shiko's wife was Namiko KUMOI who was a first graduate of Takarazuka Revue, and her daughter is actress Mikiko TSUBOUCHI.)
